isis.stitle: TSI 06-04-03 - Quality Connect Air Fitting Service Information

subjectgroup.subject: Quality Connect Air Fitting Service Information

geninfo.para: This TSI applies to all models with air systems.

International Truck and Engine Corporation has been using Quality Connect air fittings on vehicles with air systems for several years. The Quality Connect fittings are threadless. A collet in the fitting ( Figure 1) bites into the tube to hold it firmly in place. The fitting O-ring (Figure 1) seals the tube to the valve, manifold or tee body to prevent leakage. To aid in service, a kit (part number 991843C91) is available with tools for each port and tube size used by International®.
This letter contains information on how to service Quality Connect air fittings.

entry.para: The Tool Kit contains the following tools.

svcproc.title: LEAKAGE TEST
svcproc.para: Use Amprobe ultrasonic leak detector (Part Number ZTSE4800) to locate leaks. Use soap bubbles to determine severity.

A soap bubble test can be made to determine if the quality connect fitting(s) needs repair. When performing a bubble test, leakage should not exceed a soap bubble of 1/2 inch (12 mm) in 3 seconds with system air pressure of 100 to 130 psi. If the leakage exceeds these specifications, the quality connect fitting(s) should be serviced.

warning.para: To prevent personal injury or death, completely drain system of air pressure before removing.

step1.para: If a leak has been discovered and service is necessary, drain the air off the system and push the tube into the port to make sure it is fully seated.
Pressurize the system. If the leak still exceeds specifications, it will be necessary to disassemble the fitting to determine the cause of the excessive air leak.
Select the appropriate repair tools and parts for the tube size being serviced.
Use the tube release tool ( Figure 2) to remove the tube. Do this by placing it around the tube.

Push the release tool against the fitting, then pull on the tube. Pushing the tool depresses the fitting collet, allowing it to release the tube. Sometimes the brass tube support ( Figure 1) will be pulled out of the fitting when the tube is removed. Be sure to re-install a tube support when installing the tube.

If the brass tube support remains in the fitting and is undamaged, leave it in place. If it remains in the fitting but looks damaged, remove it with needle nose pliers ( Figure 3). Discard the brass tube support then install a new brass tube support of the same size. (see step 10 ). If fitting is equipped with a black molded tube support, it cannot be removed.
Inspect the port for any debris or contaminants. Remove any that are found.
Inspect the tube end for external scratches, burrs, or cracks. If it is damaged, trim the damaged portion off at an insertion depth mark ( Figure 4) or replace the tube. DO NOT re-use a damaged end.

important.para: Use the tube cutter (supplied in the tool kit) to ensure that the cut is square within 15° to help prevent leakage ( Figure 5). Do not use a dull or heavy cutting tool such as side cutters, pocket knife or hack saw which could collapse (flatten) the tube or create O-ring damaging burrs. Do not use the tube cutter to cut anything other than nylon air line tubing. Replace the blade or cutter if the cutting edge becomes dull.

step1.para: Use the forked end of the repair tool to remove the collet ( Figure 6). Discard the collet.
Remove the O-ring using the repair tool O-ring remover ( Figure 7). Discard the O-ring. Avoid scratching the O-ring cavity during removal of the O-ring.

note.para: If the O-ring cavity is scratched even slightly during removal of the O-ring, the scratch may cause the fitting to leak.

step1.para: If the tube support was removed, place it or a new one into a shipping plug (supplied in the parts kit). Press the tube support into the port until it bottoms out ( Figure 8). Remove the shipping plug with the plug removal tool.
Use an approved lubricant (preferably liquid detergent in water) and lubricate the new O-ring. Place the O-ring inside the top of the Quality Connect fitting sleeve as shown in Figure 9.
Install a new collet. Hand pressure alone is enough. It will click when it is seated properly ( Figure 10). In addition, the collet will push the O-ring into its fully seated position ( Figure 1).

If the tubing does not have an insertion depth mark, perform the following: Use the repair tool ( Figure 11) to identify the correct insertion depth for the size tubing being used. Mark the correct insertion depth on the tube.

Lubricate the tube end with an approved lubricant (preferably liquid detergent in water)and install it to the correct insertion depth ( Figure 12). Install the tube by pushing it straight into the fitting. The insertion depth mark should be flush with the face of the fitting ( Figure 12). Gently tug on the tube to make sure it is secured in the fitting.

Test to make sure the assembly is free from leaks using a soap solution and clean, dry air at system pressure. If a leak exceeding specifications (refer to Leakage Test) is still present, remove and replace the valve, manifold or tee.
To use an unused port, first remove the shipping plug with the plug removal tool. This can be done by depressing the collet, then pulling out the plug ( Figure 13).

Use the repair tool ( Figure 14) to identify the correct insertion depth for the size tubing being used. Mark the correct insertion depth on the tube. If tubing with insertion depth marks is being used, trim the end of the tubing at an insertion mark using a recommended tube cutter. Refer to FIELD SERVICE, Step 7 for tube cutting information.

Lubricate the tube with an approved lubricant (preferably liquid detergent in water)and install it to the correct insertion depth. Install the tube by pushing it straight into the fitting. The insertion depth mark should be flush with the face of the fitting ( Figure 15). Gently tug on the tube to make sure it is secured in the fitting.

Test to make sure the assembly is free from leaks using a soap solution and clean, dry air at system pressure. If the fitting leak exceeds specifications (refer to Leakage Test) perform the FIELD SERVICE procedure.
